title: How to choose your news - Damon Brown

multiple-choice.question: How do most people today get information about what's happening in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a couple of general interest magazines and newspapers of record.

options.label: B
options.text: Through three or four TV networks with trusted newscasters.

options.label: C
options.text: Through a vast array of sources, including social media, blogs, and online video.

options.label: D
options.text: Through word of mouth and community newsletters.

multiple-choice.question: What led to the breakdown of trust in media gatekeepers in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: The rise of the Internet and social media.

options.label: B
options.text: Revelations of covert wars, secret assassinations, and political corruption.

options.label: C
options.text: The increasing popularity of alternative newspapers and radio shows.

options.label: D
options.text: The growing number of journalists and reporters.

multiple-choice.question: How can you get the truth or something close to it in today's media landscape?

options.label: A
options.text: By relying on a single trusted news source.

options.label: B
options.text: By getting the original news unfiltered by middlemen.

options.label: C
options.text: By following only well-established journalists and reporters.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring social media and online video.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to be cautious when following major events in real-time?

options.label: A
options.text: Because you might miss important updates.

options.label: B
options.text: Because you might get too much information at once.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the information may be incorrect or incomplete.

options.label: D
options.text: Because you might get anxious or overwhelmed.

multiple-choice.question: How can you separate fact from opinion when consuming news?

options.label: A
options.text: By looking for words like "think," "likely," or "probably."

options.label: B
options.text: By relying on anonymous sources.

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring reports that contradict your own opinions.

options.label: D
options.text: By only reading news from well-established outlets.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential problem with reports that rely on anonymous sources?

options.label: A
options.text: The sources may have little connection to the story.

options.label: B
options.text: The sources may have an interest in influencing coverage.

options.label: C
options.text: The sources may be unaccountable for the information they provide.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to verify news before spreading it?

options.label: A
options.text: Because social media has enabled the truth to reach us faster.

options.label: B
options.text: Because rumors and falsehoods can spread quickly and be difficult to refute.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's always better to be safe than sorry.

options.label: D
options.text: Because you might get in trouble for spreading false information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of reading coverage from multiple outlets?

options.label: A
options.text: You can get a more complete picture of the story.

options.label: B
options.text: You can avoid conflicting information.

options.label: C
options.text: You can rely on a single trusted source.

options.label: D
options.text: You can ignore reports that contradict your own opinions.

multiple-choice.question: How has the media landscape changed in recent decades?

options.label: A
options.text: It has become more centralized and controlled.

options.label: B
options.text: It has become more diverse and decentralized.

options.label: C
options.text: It has remained largely the same.

options.label: D
options.text: It has become more biased and partisan.

multiple-choice.question: What is the responsibility that comes with the freedom to curate our own media experience?

options.label: A
options.text: The responsibility to seek out only information that confirms our own opinions.

options.label: B
options.text: The responsibility to ignore reports that contradict our own opinions.

options.label: C
options.text: The responsibility to verify information and seek out multiple sources.

options.label: D
options.text: The responsibility to rely on a single trusted news source.
